comments.commentBody: Piazza is the interesting one- whispers but no public alegations. Murray Chass wrote about back acne, but I don't remember a reporter accusing him publically- will be interesting to see how the writers handle it.

As a baseball fan, I'm sad to hear about Jason Bay's injury.  There's such a fine line these players walk between performing every day, every play, and seriously injuring themselves.  Hope that Jason gets well.

Dick,
Thank you. It's about time someone stated the obvious.

Thank you from my heart for this, Mr. Cavett. Too many of us have become cruel and unthinking, cavalierly putting aside what our religions teach us (and we say we believe in) and what our education was meant to have instilled in us. When the people of the United States froth at the mouth over the freedoms we espouse for ourselves, we stand on parlous ground (zero) indeed.

Thank you!!!! Thank you!!!! Thank you!!!! Thank you!!!! Thank you!!!!

My only regret about the article is the paean to privet property -- it is so unnecessary, a sop to the capitalistic/ materialistic right; not much better than Obama's retreat. Morality/ human decency needs no material justification.
I read until the point you referred to Harry Reid as a man of integrety, at which point you lost all credibility.
kindly and confidently agree to disagree  on this one

You said it. Even the discussion of this is a victory to America's enemies. It seems far too many Americans who purport to love their country, find some of its basic freedoms an inconvenience. My father-in-law claimed to be "all for freedom of speech" but felt that it should be suspended in times of war. This type of equivocation with our basic freedoms is all too commonly held in this country. The mosque controversy but the latest example.
And isn't it sad to think that in this, of all countries, there's going to be a book burning?
Thanks again, Mr. Cavett for so eloquently expressing what many of us are feeling. And hear hear to your 6th grade self. What a brave lad!

DON'T forget when brown played the hashmarks were further apart which made it difficult to run to the short side.....

Is there a point to this?  I find more interesting the differences in their careers.  Why does possibly the greatest running back in history retire 'prematurely'?  Because he played on a team that with the exception of one or two seasons was not committed to winning.  It is obvious that when your team commits to winning, even greater individual achievements are possible.  Hence, Barry Sanders.  Hence Emmitt Smith.

Portland is one of the east coasts great beer cities.stop in at the Great Lost Bear and have a few NE craft beers.60 taps or so.good place to start a portland beer crawl...great bar food too!

theres gritty mcduffs, a whole spate of craft breweries to tour and beer bars and cafes to quaff and stuff your mouth.
had family in north conway NH and id drive down here for a few beers dinner and some harbor side fun.and that was about ten years ago-scene is even better now i believe-

highly reccomended.

So it's Yma Sumac (singer) & Uma Thurman (actress), hey. I remember Ms Thurman from Pulp Fiction, but couldn't remember who got which vowel. (The cross cleared things up.)

I didn't know COZEN, but was pretty sure ASPI ended with an N. I looked up Les Aspin and I can't say I remember him at all.

If I had known that only B vitamins are "complex", I wouldn't have made the careless error in OJIBWA.

-- jpgaskell

The Portland Museum of Art is honoring the centennial of Winslow Homer's death with "Winslow Homer and the Poetics of Place" through Sept. 6, 2010.BOSTON GLOBE,Sebastian Smee,August 7, 2010 in "This must be the place""An age for the telling moment" says "The Portland Museum of Art has impressive holdings of Homer" showing 28 works "all drawn from the Museum's collection","Homer is considered the greatest of all American watercolorists."WALL STREET JOURNAL,Terry Teachout, July 10, 2010 in "This must be the Place" says "a visit to Maine will change the way you look at art","To spend time in Maine is to be taught a priceless lesson in how to look at representational art." NEW YORK SUN,Seth Lipsky, August 12, 2010,in "A Brilliant Showing at the Portland Museum of Art" said "Winslow Homer and the Poetics of Place get a Brilliant Showing at the Portland Museum of Art","In a jewel of a museum show","This show is just not to be missed."

The tendency is to blame the men. But enough studies have shown that the men are often not wanted around the house, or feel belittled. It is a matri-focal society, girls having babies who as girls have babies. 1) get contraceptives available in all public places cheap or free, 2) get serious about gender equality in family life-- treat men as husbands and parents, not "deadbeat" pocketbooks, with "Presumptive Equal Parenting" in applied to every birth- and parental equality should be the norm in all states,(contrary to the National Organization for Women propaganda). 3) Debtor's prison is unconstitutional- STOP it. 4) And make schools more boy-friendly with men teachers.

Mr.Herbert: Polls indicate that black voters still support President Obama in large numbers which is something I do not understand. Surely they must see the increasing devastation surrounding them and his lackluster ability to create programs for black men when there are so many needs for young strength in our nation.
If we can pay the tremendous costs of waging useless wars in which many minorities are forced to enlist, it is more vital that we support a more important kind of army to repair our country instead of destroying other nations and people.
I agree that we need our black leaders to reinstate the energy and purpose of the Civil Rights movement and organize jobs programs. I am surprised this hasn't become a number one priority. We have learned unfortunately, that depending on a leader who has a dark skin is no guarantee that the man in charge will see the pain in the eyes of all the black voters who supported him.
I am haunted by those hopeful faces at President Obama's inauguration, and as a white progressive woman am deeply angered at his betrayal of so many of us, especially of the struggling members of his own race.

It seems that this cliched sentiment has been the same for the past fifty years. In every decade, we hear that African-American males are statistically wronged and genetically cursed.

Yet why do I, a white male, meet and admire and respect so many African-American males in my daily life? Some have jobs that pay more than me and some are not working, but I see a strength in character, in human feeling, in a depth of spiritual devotion, that I do not see very often in my non-Black friends.

When can we move beyond the racial prison that categorizes everything and makes a mockery of individual thought, individual failing or individual achievement? Let some men fail, let some men succeed, but stop, please stop, once and for all, with this vast, sweeping and utterly irrational generalizing about the condition of dark skinned Americans.

An equal level of education for every child in America would be a start. That would give poverty-stricken kids a fighting chance for employability. If there is hope of employment, then there may be some hope for their future. I can only imagine what it must be like to be born into total hopelessness and closed doors everywhere, as it is now. I don't like living in a society with a permanent underclass. It's not right.
